questions.question: Why does the student peak with the professor?

selections.information: To ask for assistance coming up with an idea for her assignment
To go over an article the professor had assigned
To discuss an architectural concept she would like to work with
To review her work on a project she recently submitted

questions.question: What point do the speakers make when they discuss the materials used in the iceberg design?

selections.information: The materials are designed to help cool the building
The materials are more costly than building materials typically used in urban structures
The thickness of materials requires that they be cut with special equipment
The amount of materials used reduced the impact on the environment

questions.question: Why does the professor mention retail space?

selections.information: To explain the cause of city developer’s tax problem
To introduce the focus of the class’s next model project
To point out how quickly modern retail structures are built
To provide background on why the iceberg design was created

questions.question: What does the professor say about air beams?

selections.information: They provide support to the iceberg
They are made partly from steel
They permit an iceberg to assume a variety of shapes
They take a long time to manufacture

questions.question: What can be inferred about the student?

selections.information: She was not fully aware of the trip’s date
She does not intend to go on the trip
She had already been to the Frank LIoyd Wright house
She would prefer to lead the tour, not be a group member

questions.question: What is the lecture mainly about?

selections.information: The life of a famous Italian Renaissance artist
The history of fresco painting in Italy
The creation of a particular work of Renaissance art
The construction of a typical church of the Italian Renaissance

questions.question: According to the professor, what is one advantage of using the fresco technique?

selections.information: A fresco can last a long time
The materials for making a fresco are inexpensive
The fresco technique is easy to learn
A fresco can be completed quickly

questions.question: According to the professor, why is a fresco painted before the plaster dries?

selections.information: So that mistakes can be corrected easily
So that the paint will sink into the plaster
So that the colors of the paints can be blended better
So that human forms will appear more lifelike

questions.question: Why does the professor mention the artist who painted with a paintbrush in each hand?

selections.information: To describe how the Sistine Chapel’s ceiling was painted
To illustrate the ingenious creativity of Renaissance artists
To explain how Michelangelo learned to paint
To emphasize the need for fresco painters to work quickly

questions.question: Why did Michelangelo choose to build footbridges rather than traditional scaffolding when he painted the chapel?

selections.information: To accommodate the curved shape of the chapel’s ceiling
To keep the floor clear for ceremonies in the chapel
To reach both the walls and the ceiling of the chapel
To paint while lying on his back for long periods of time

questions.question: What does the professor imply when he says this?

selections.information: He has suggestions about how students can deal with difficult situations
Many people would have been uncomfortable painting the chapel’s ceiling
There was one problem that Michelangelo was unable to overcome
Michelangelo’s reputation as a great artist may be somewhat exaggerated

questions.question: What does the professor mainly discuss?

selections.information: The main achievements of the Voyager spacecraft mission
Differences between Uranus and other gas giant planets
Reasons for the increasing interest of scientists in the planet Uranus
Characteristics of Uranus learned using a variety of methods

questions.question: Why does the professor mention the color of Uranus?

selections.information: To give an example of a feature that Uranus shares with Jupiter
To give an example of a discovery made by the Voyager spacecraft mission
To explain how a component of Uranus’ atmosphere was identified
To explain how sunlight affects temperatures on Uranus

questions.question: According to the professor, how did astronomers deduce the composition of the planet Uranus?

selections.information: By calculating Uranus’ density
By measuring Uranus’ force of gravity
By examining the strength of Uranus’ magnetic field
By comparing Uranus with Jupiter

questions.question: What features of Uranus do some astronomers think were caused by the planet’s collision with another object?

selections.information: The composition of its core
The angle of its axis of rotation
Its rapid rotation
Its low internal temperature

questions.question: Why does the professor mention Uranus’ magnetic field?

selections.information: To point out a surprising similarity between Uranus and Earth
To emphasize the limitations of remote observations in astronomy
To point out a recent discovery about Uranus that contradicts earlier findings
To explain one effect of Uranus’ distance from the Sun

questions.question: Why does the professor say this?

selections.information: To suggest that the student’s question reflects a common misconception
To remind the student that they will discuss rocky planets in the next class
To help the student realize the answer to his own question
To encourage the student to clarify what he means

questions.question: Why does the woman go to see the man?

selections.information: To provide feedback on her previous housing experience
To find out how she can participate in a different housing program
To reapply for housing at the Eco House next semester
To get information about a student assistant position

questions.question: What is the woman’s attitude about the Eco House?

selections.information: She had hoped it would be more committed to sustainable practices
She believes that its program is exactly what she will need
She thinks its program is too narrow for her academic goals
She regrets that residents are only permitted to live there for one year

questions.question: What are two advantages of living at the Mary Blake House?

selections.information: It would allow her to actively engage with guest scholars
It would allow her to create a house theme with other students
She would join a classmate who currently lives at the Mary Blake House
She would have an opportunity to qualify for staff discounts

questions.question: Why does the woman mention a journalist?

selections.information: To provide background on one of the faculty living at the Mary Blake House
To provide an example of a recent dinner guest at the Mary Blake House
To suggest a way to create publicity for the Mary Blake House program
To point out a Blake House program guest that she would be interested in

questions.question: What does the man ask the woman to do?

selections.information: Fill out a questionnaire about the Mary Blake House program
Participate in a review of program houses that is being conducted
Interview to become a student assistant at the Eco House
Provide feedback about the application process on the Web site

questions.question: What is the purpose of the lecture?

selections.information: To suggest that cryptic patterns in the animal kingdom can be reduced to only a few basic forms
To explain how cephalopods change cryptic patterns based on their visual perception
To contrast underwater and dryland crypsis strategies
To trace the evolution of crypsis in animals as a defense against predators

questions.question: What can be inferred about an animal that only uses stipple crypsis?

selections.information: It will have a difficult time hiding from predators
It is likely to be of a medium body size
It will tend to avoid areas with multiple colors and patterns
It will most likely be found close to a seashore

questions.question: What happens to some cephalopods when they swim over a gravel patch on the seafloor?

selections.information: They change their skin color to match the color of the darkest pieces of gravel
They display irregularly shaped dark and light patches
They display a disruptive coloration to match the local environment
They quickly swim away from the gravel patch

questions.question: What features of disruptive crypsis does the professor mention?

selections.information: It disguises the outline of the animal that uses it
It works by contrasting with the colors in the surrounding habitat
It is most effective when used against a single-colored background
It can incorporate a combination of other crypsis patterns

questions.question: Why does the professor mention the tiger?

selections.information: To illustrate that results of the cephalopod research can be extended to many other animals
To give an example of an animal whose crypsis strategy has been extensively studied
To point out how different its crypsis strategy is from the strategy used by smaller animals
To argue that predators rely on crypsis less than prey species do

questions.question: What does the professor imply when she says this?

selections.information: Crypsis in cephalopods can rarely fool human visual perception
Few animals use crypsis to hide from predators
New information has led to the reevaluation of some previous assumptions
More cephalopod research needs to be done to obtain accurate data

questions.question: What is the main purpose of the lecture?

selections.information: To discuss the design of the earliest homes built in the eastern Mediterranean
To discuss evidence indicating a change of lifestyle among a group of prehistoric people
To compare evidence of early human settlement in different regions of the world
To compare different techniques used to process grains in the eastern Mediterranean

questions.question: According to the professor, what was one way in which hunter-gatherers benefited after the glaciers retreated?

selections.information: The warmer climate allowed them to build simpler, lighter houses
The appearance of open grasslands provided easier access to food
An increase in the number of lakes attracted more migrating animals
An increase in annual rainfall made farming more productive

questions.question: Why does the professor describe features of Natufian sites?

selections.information: The features indicate that the Natufians established the largest early human settlement in the world
The sites contain the first strong evidence of hunting by prehistoric people
Compelling evidence of a sedentary lifestyle is available at the sites
Artifacts at the sites are well preserved because of the region’s dry climate

questions.question: What evidence found by researchers does the professor describe to show that the Natufians were NOT a nomadic people?

selections.information: Tools that were too heavy to move very far
Large structures used for storing grain
Stone enclosures that separated one home from another
Underground foundations for houses
Remains of certain animals

questions.question: What point does the professor make about young gazelles and migratory birds?

selections.information: They were believed to be scared animals by the Natufians
They lived near open grasslands
They were the most common animals found in the regions
They would have been present at the site at different seasons

questions.question: Why does the professor say this?

selections.information: To prevent a misunderstanding
To explain how agriculture began
To define a technical term
To signal a change of topic
